title: Pensioners scammed out of £6m in wine investment fraud
description: Victims invested life savings before being overcharged – sometimes over 400pc
content:
Three men have been convicted for a fraudulent investment scheme that stole £6m from 41 victims.

Benjamin Cazaly, 42, and Gregory Assemakis, 39, both from Kent, alongside Dominic D’Sa, 45, from London, were found guilty of fraudulent trading on Tuesday at St Albans Crown Court.

Imperial Wine & Spirits Merchants, founded as Imperial Wines of London by Cazaly, is believed to have handled £37m during the 10 years it was trading, according to Hertfordshire Trading Standards.

It added that victims were scammed into investing their life savings into the wine industry before being overcharged – sometimes by over 400 per cent.

It is believed that the men used films to learn manipulation techniques such as cold calling and following scripts to persuade pensioners to hand over their money.

Victims were also sent brochures featuring logos from The Telegraph and the Financial Times without permission.

The company, which claimed to be a family-run investment house with offices in Paris and Hong Kong, was actually based in a call centre in Groveland Court, central London.

Trading Standards raided the building in 2018, finding mantras such as “no means yes” on the wall.

Hertfordshire council said the jury heard a recording in which a woman was asked for her card details despite not knowing what a payment card was.

Trish Burls, from National Trading Standards, said: “Victims in this case lost thousands of pounds through a co-ordinated scam of lies, deceit and manipulation.

“The criminals exploited people’s passion and enthusiasm, preying on them to invest while stripping many of their life savings and causing significant emotional distress.”

Ajanta Hilton, executive member for community safety at Hertfordshire county council, said: “The stories of those targeted with this investment scam are devastating.

“I’d like to thank them for their bravery in telling their stories so that these callous criminals could be brought to justice.”
summary: Three men have been convicted of fraudulent trading for a fraudulent investment scheme that stole £6m from 41 pensioners. Benjamin Cazaly, Gregory Assemakis, and Dominic D’Sa, all from Kent, and Imperial Wine & Spirits Merchants, founded as Imperial Wines of London, stole over £37m over the course of ten years. The scam involved pensioners investing their life savings into the wine industry, often overcharged by over 400%%. The men used techniques such as cold calling and following scripts to persuade them to hand over their money. The company, which claimed to be a family-run investment house with offices in Paris and Hong Kong, was actually based in a call centre in Groveland Court, central London.
shortSummary: Three men were convicted for a £6m fraud involving Imperial Wine & Spirits Merchants, which conned 41 victims out of their life savings.
argos_summary: Three men, Benjamin Cazaly, Gregory Assemakis, and Dominic D’Sa, were convicted for a fraudulent investment scheme that defrauded 41 victims of £6 million. They operated Imperial Wine & Spirits Merchants, falsely presenting it as a legitimate investment firm while using manipulative tactics to persuade individuals, particularly pensioners, to invest their life savings. The scheme involved overcharging and deceptive marketing practices, leading to significant emotional and financial distress for the victims.
